ctas.heading: ModulaCMS
ctas.subheading: A modern headless CMS built in Go. One binary, three servers — HTTP, HTTPS, and SSH. Manage your content from the terminal or the API.

children.text:
Why ModulaCMS?

Most headless CMS platforms are bloated SaaS products or sprawling Node.js applications. ModulaCMS takes a different approach: a single Go binary that compiles with zero runtime dependencies. Deploy it anywhere Linux or macOS runs.

Content is structured as a composable tree â pages contain rows, rows contain columns, columns contain components like text, rich text, images, CTAs, and cards. Every piece of content is a node in a doubly-linked sibling list, enabling O(1) reordering without renumbering.

The built-in SSH server runs a full terminal UI powered by Bubbletea. SSH in, manage your content, create routes, configure datatypes â all without leaving your terminal. For programmatic access, the REST API covers everything the TUI can do and more.

cards.description: Run on SQLite for local development, PostgreSQL for production, or MySQL if that is what you have. One codebase, three database backends, zero config changes beyond a single field in config.json.
cards.title: Tri-Database Support

cards.description: SSH into your CMS and manage everything from a rich terminal UI built with Bubbletea. Create content, configure datatypes, manage users and roles — all without opening a browser.
cards.title: Terminal-First Management

cards.description: A complete REST API with role-based access control, audited mutations, and multi-format response output. Deliver content in Contentful, Sanity, Strapi, WordPress, or clean JSON formats.
cards.title: Headless REST API

children.text:
Architecture

ModulaCMS is built around a few core principles: simplicity of deployment, flexibility of storage, and composability of content.

Single Binary, Three Servers

The serve command starts HTTP, HTTPS (with automatic Let's Encrypt certificates), and SSH servers concurrently. Graceful shutdown handles the first signal cleanly; a second signal forces immediate exit.

Content as a Tree

Every piece of content is a node in a tree structure. Pages sit at the root. Rows, columns, and components nest beneath them. Sibling ordering uses a doubly-linked list for O(1) insertions and moves. Datatypes define the schema for each node type, and fields define the individual data points within each datatype.

Audited Mutations

Every write operation is recorded as a change event with the operation type, old and new values, request metadata, and timestamps. This provides a complete audit trail and lays the groundwork for replication.

RBAC Authorization

Three bootstrap roles â admin, editor, and viewer â provide granular resource:operation permissions. The permission cache uses build-then-swap for lock-free reads. Every admin endpoint is wrapped with permission middleware. The system is fail-closed: missing permissions always result in a 403.

SDKs

Official SDKs are available for TypeScript (read-only and admin), Go, and Swift. All SDKs mirror the API surface with typed IDs, branded types, and full CRUD support.
